message.content: This question tests understanding of the phenomenon of refraction and how rainbows are formed. When light passes through a medium with different densities (such as water droplets in the air), it bends or refracts, causing the colors to separate and form a rainbow. Option (B) is the correct answer because shining a flashlight on a gem can replicate the refraction of light and splitting into different colors, just like a rainbow. Option (A) is incorrect because watching sunlight bounce off a mirror does not involve refraction. Option (C) is also incorrect because shining a flashlight at a mirror does not involve refraction. Option (D) is unrelated to the phenomenon of rainbows and refraction.

This question requires knowledge about the phenomenon of refraction and how rainbows are formed. When light passes through a medium with different densities (such as air and water), it bends or refracts. This bending of light causes the different colors to separate, resulting in a rainbow. Option (B) is the correct answer because shining a flashlight on a gem can simulate the refraction of light and splitting it into different colors. Option (A) is incorrect because bouncing sunlight off a mirror does not involve refraction. Option (C) is incorrect because shining a flashlight at a mirror does not involve refraction either. Option (D) is incorrect because looking at a freshly formed diamond does not involve the refraction of light.

This question tests knowledge of the phenomenon of refraction and how rainbows are formed. When light passes through a medium of a different refractive index (such as air and water), it bends or refracts. This bending of light causes it to separate into its different colors, creating a rainbow. Option (B) is the correct answer because when a flashlight is shone on a gemstone, the light is refracted and split into different colors, similar to how sunlight is refracted in raindrops to form a rainbow. Option (A) is incorrect because watching sunlight bounce off a mirror does not involve refraction. Option (C) is also incorrect because shining a flashlight at a mirror does not involve refraction. Option (D) is misleading because the formation of a rainbow requires the refraction of light and does not directly relate to a freshly formed diamond.

This question requires basic knowledge about the formation of a rainbow and the phenomenon of refraction. A rainbow is formed when sunlight undergoes refraction and dispersion as it passes through raindrops in the atmosphere. The raindrops act as tiny prisms that break the white light into its component colors. Option (B) is correct because shining a flashlight on a gem can mimic the effect of passing light through a prism, splitting the light into different colors. Option (A) is incorrect because watching sunlight bounce off a mirror does not involve the refraction of light. Option (C) is incorrect because shining a flashlight at a mirror does not involve passing light through a prism. Option (D) is incorrect because looking at a freshly formed diamond does not involve passing light through a prism.
